content:
Normally, Thunderbird would prompt if server is refusing due to incorrect password. All I can think of would be to either manually add the password to Thunderbird, or to remove what is there to allow a prompt. Here goes: - click settings>privacy&security - click saved passwords and then show passwords - highlight the incoming server row and rightclick and select 'edit password'

OR... - from same place, highlight the incoming and outgoing rows and delete.
creator: davidsk

creator: colin.jannaway

content: That is an example of the level of support some email providers give. No email client could ever give that error message. The message is being generated by a TalkTalk server. I did a quick web search on this error message and noticed there are others out there who report to their email provider and are ignored. In this case, Thunderbird isn't even involved. Message goes from the sender's email server to the TalkTalk server which responds back. They are ignoring the problem.

content:
Dates follow the operating system locale. It is most certainly not hard coded. Being force fed mm-DD date formats would have this Aussie firing chips at all Mozilla and Mzla employees that poked their heads up. Interestingly these types of questions most often come from Linux users where open source has led to setting a system locale being a chore and setting such details in your chosen windowing environment does not necessarily affect the system locale.

I suggest you check with your distribution how to check your locale and set it, including the date formats.
creator: MattAuSupport

I will guess your provider has issues today, or changed the settings required to connect, or your antivirus updated and choked on it's breakfast so mail does not work.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird has had a profile per install process since V68. The result of this is that transferring data has become immeasurably more difficult in recent versions.

I really do not understand what your cutting and pasting of templates etc actually means. What did you do? Note if your are pasting anything into an IMAP account, especially at the file level failure is guaranteed at around 99% confidence.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Please give more information, such as whether this is a POP or IMAP account. If a POP account, and if account was set to delete from server after download, then they are probably lost. If an IMAP account, then nothing is lost and you would just need to reestablish the account. You can verify what files are still available by logging on to your email provider's website account. Of course, if you made a backup, we can help in recovering it. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content:
I will preempt this by saying I have my own personal issues with supernova. I am not an evangelist.

The first thing to consider is what software on your computer might be in a position to make a program think it has no disk space and can not open files? Everyone jumps to "malware" but in reality if you have a third party antivirus, or internet security suite, it is probably the issue.

Yes I am taking your issues out of order, but I think that that is the key issue. Repopulating something from a disk file being slow is probably related to the inability to read and write to the disk. Beyond the simplicity of the antivirus being the issue (restarting the operating system in safe mode with networking ios considered the standard diagnostic to eliminate outside influences like Av and other software like cloud sync and streaming backups which can also mimic no file access.

When it comes to folder counts of unread and total messages. Unread messages in sub folders are included in the count for their parent when collapsed as demonstrated below in a trash folder.

If you want to have a discussion about a crash, please provide the submitted crash report id so we can look at it. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/mozilla-crash-reporter-tb#w_viewing-crash-reports
creator: MattAuSupport
